@bender Ux is hard ü§Ø

Speaking of Git hosting / forges / thingies‚Ä¶ I just realised that the way in which sr.ht manages patches is actually very similar to what I had in mind, at least conceptually. And‚Ä¶ it looks like they somehow have figured out a way to represent whether or not the patches were applied in this nifty Web UI ‚Äì If you follow the link to a proposed patch for example you also get another nice interface explaining how to deal with the patch ‚Äì As well as a nifty (if you expand it out) little CLI snippet you can paste into your Terminal like:

$ curl -s https://lists.sr.ht/~migadu/alps-devel/patches/36196/mbox | git am -3

Neat! üëå Some good inspiration to draw from there‚Ä¶ (even if I still don‚Äôt like the idea of using Email).

content.html:
↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Learn to use email with git! -- Interesting read of how to use the "Git Email" workflow for sending patches to a project ü§î Not sure how I feel about it though üòÖ

@marado Yeah so @lyse@lyse.isobeef.org and I are talking on IRC right now about an idea I had about this‚Ä¶ I realise I could use the same git patch/diff format(s) but skip the Email parts. I was even thinking of using Twtxt itself as a sort of ‚Äúnotification‚Äù and some kind of easy-to-use web-based push/pull system for managing the patches and applying them to your repo(s).

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Learn to use email with git! -- Interesting read of how to use the "Git Email" workflow for sending patches to a project ü§î Not sure how I feel about it though üòÖ

@justamoment Yeah, not only that, but one of the ‚Äúissues‚Äù I have with the whole Git+Email patch workflow in general is that you have to basically ‚Äúgive up‚Äù your identity, email address and personal information in some way. I find that a bit bothersome really. ‚Äì I‚Äôm sure we can come up with a proper ‚Äúdecentralised‚Äù way of collaborating on software with git as the primary backend for revision history and patches, but hmmm ü§î

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Learn to use email with git! Patch Workflows - Ry‚Äôs Git Tutorial - RyPress -- Another good blog post on working with Git patches via Email as well as applying them. -- The key point (I think) is that you need to grab the entire contents of email email in order in order to pipe the contents into git am - -- Hmmm ü§î -- I think we can do better than this...

@justamoment Well what I mean to say is that git itself basically just houses some client-side ‚ÄúMetadata‚Äù about the repository and a bunch of objects that make up the contents and revision history. For example, there is a special file called .git/description that you can edit and there‚Äôs even git branch --edit to edit a branch‚Äôs description. But none of that is useful beyond a local client. That is to say, if you git clone or git push none of that information is published anywhere or made available to anyone else.

So Git‚Äôs ‚Äúdistributed data‚Äù is limited to well basically its revision history and series of objects I guess? ü§î

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Learn to use email with git! Patch Workflows - Ry‚Äôs Git Tutorial - RyPress -- Another good blog post on working with Git patches via Email as well as applying them. -- The key point (I think) is that you need to grab the entire contents of email email in order in order to pipe the contents into git am - -- Hmmm ü§î -- I think we can do better than this...

@justamoment Hmmm so there isn‚Äôt a lot you can do with plain Git itself. Even patches sent via email are basisally out-or-band at that point.

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Learn to use email with git! -- Interesting read of how to use the "Git Email" workflow for sending patches to a project ü§î Not sure how I feel about it though üòÖ

@justamoment From the maitainrr side you just end up having to copy the raw contents of the emails and pipe them into git am - in the right order. It‚Äôs a bit tedious ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Learn to use email with git!
